resources: "A a perfect substitute ENDSTOPB an imperfect substitute ENDSTOPC a perfect complement ENDSTOPD an imperfect complement" "A a rightward shift of the demand curve for Good X ENDSTOPB a leftward shift of the demand curve for Good X ENDSTOPC a movement along the demand curve for Good X from left to right ENDSTOPD a movement along the demand curve for Good X from right to left" "A a rise in the quantity demanded of whisky by 20 per cent ENDSTOPB a rise in the quantity demanded of whisky by 10 per cent ENDSTOPC a fall in the quantity demanded of whisky by 20 per cent ENDSTOPD a fall in the quantity demanded of whisky by 10 per cent" "A shift the entire budget line to the left ENDSTOPB shift the entire budget line to the right ENDSTOPC make the budget line steeper ENDSTOPD make the budget line less steep" "A a rightward shift of the demand curve for Good X ENDSTOPB a leftward shift of the demand curve for Good X ENDSTOPC a movement along the demand curve for Good X from left to right ENDSTOPD a movement along the demand curve for Good X from right to left" "A Investment A dominates Investment ENDSTOPB in over 50% of possible scenarios. B Investment A has a lower standard deviation of returns than Investment B. ENDSTOPC Investment A dominates Investment B in 100% of possible scenarios. ENDSTOPD Investment A has a higher expected rate of return than Investment B." "A The taking out of an insurance policy makes it more likely that the insured against event will occur than if no insurance policy is taken out. ENDSTOPB Insurance companies tend to select only good risk customers. ENDSTOPC Bad risk customers are able to obtain insurance on the same terms as good risk customers. ENDSTOPD People who know they are particularly bad risks are more inclined to take out insurance than those who know they are good risks." "A £81 ENDSTOPB £9 ENDSTOPC £1 ENDSTOPD -£1" "A Average product can never be above marginal product. ENDSTOPB Average product can never be less than marginal product. ENDSTOPC Marginal product can never become negative. ENDSTOPD Average product can never become negative." "A a consumer’s utility will rise ENDSTOPB a consumer’s utility will be unchanged ENDSTOPC a consumer’s utility will fall ENDSTOPD a consumer’s money income is unchanged" "A M0, M1, M4 but not M3 ENDSTOPB M0 and M4, but not M1 and M3 ENDSTOPC M0, but not M1, M3 and M4 ENDSTOPD M0, M1, M3 and M4" "A Increasing returns to scale. ENDSTOPB Constant returns to scale. ENDSTOPC Decreasing returns to scale. ENDSTOPD The law of diminishing marginal returns." "A average fixed costs ENDSTOPB average variable costs ENDSTOPC average total costs ENDSTOPD average normal profit level" "A lower the price and raise output ENDSTOPB maintain the existing price and output ENDSTOPC lower the price but maintain existing output ENDSTOPD maintain the existing price and raise output" "A An increase in local government expenditure. ENDSTOPB An increase in grants from central government to nationalised industries. ENDSTOPC An increase in transfer payments to recipients of state welfare benefits. ENDSTOPD An increase in the interest rate paid on the national debt." "A S = I ENDSTOPB S + T + M = I + G + X ENDSTOPC S + T + X = M + T + G ENDSTOPD None of the above" "A 20 ENDSTOPB 15 ENDSTOPC 10 ENDSTOPD none of the above" "A 0.1 ENDSTOPB 0.9 ENDSTOPC 0.8 ENDSTOPD 0.7" "A A decrease in the marginal propensity to save. ENDSTOPB A decrease in the marginal propensity to consume. ENDSTOPC A decrease in the marginal rate of taxation. ENDSTOPD A decrease in the marginal propensity to import." "A Real interest rates are negative if the expected rate of inflation exceeds the nominal rate of interest. ENDSTOPB Assuming a constant price level, a rise in nominal wages is also a rise in real wages. ENDSTOPC An increase in real income will lead to a reduced demand for real money balances. ENDSTOPD If nominal Gross Domestic Product (GDP) rises by 10 per cent and the GDP deflator rises by 5 per cent then real GDP has risen." "A The annual gap between total government tax receipts and total government expenditure. ENDSTOPB The total amount owed by a country to the rest of the world. ENDSTOPC The net accumulation of a country’s budget deficits. ENDSTOPD The net accumulation of a country’s current account deficits in the balance of payments." "A Country ENDSTOPB has a comparative advantage in the production of Good X. B Country B has a comparative advantage in the production of both Good X and Good Y. ENDSTOPC Country B has a comparative advantage in the production of Good Y. ENDSTOPD Country B has no comparative advantage in the production of either good." "A A rise in the money supply, a fall in the short term rate of interest and a fall in the price of treasury bills. ENDSTOPB A rise in the money supply, a fall in the short term rate of interest and a rise in the price of treasury bills. ENDSTOPC A rise in the money supply, a rise in the short term rate of interest and a fall in the price of treasury bills. ENDSTOPD A rise in the money supply, a rise in the short term rate of interest and a rise in the price of treasury bills." "A £300 million, £200 million. ENDSTOPB £300 million, -£200 million. ENDSTOPC £200 million, £300 million. ENDSTOPD £200 million, -£300 million." "A £25 million ENDSTOPB £24 million ENDSTOPC £20 million ENDSTOPD £6.25 million" "A An appreciation of a country’s exchange rate will increase its import volumes and decrease its export volumes. ENDSTOPB An appreciation of a country’s exchange rate will increase its import expenditure and decrease its export revenues. ENDSTOPC A depreciation of country’s exchange rate will decrease its import volumes and decrease its export volumes. ENDSTOPD A depreciation of a country’s exchange rate will decrease its import expenditure and increase its export revenues."
